posts.name: Amodh Naik
posts.cooked:
Hello all,
For some reason the answer I am getting for Q2 and Q3 do not seem to be in the available list of options.
I have created a pandas dataframe with row=column=business ID, where every cell is the distance between row-business ID and column-business ID. After that, I counted the number of locations within 544 and 572m of each other as asked of me by the two questions respectively.

For Q2 I got 205592, but the four options are 205,839 - 205,842.
Similarly, for Q3 I got 221478, but the four options are 220,793 - 220,796.

Please advise as to common mistakes that I may have made, because as you can see, my answers are fairly close, yet just slightly off. Any advice would be massively appreciated!

posts.name: Amodh Naik
posts.cooked:
I would like to add that I have attempted using geodesic and geopy.distance just to make sure I wasn’t going wrong in my calculations. As far as I can tell, the dataframes generated by both are identical, as are the answers they gave.
Moreover, a lot of businesses are at the exact same long & lat, giving a distance of 0 between them. I have counted them too.
I have not counted duplicates or entries where the row and column business ID are the same.

posts.name: Rajat Shenoi
posts.cooked:
AmodhNaik:

Moreover, a lot of businesses are at the exact same long & lat, giving a distance of 0 between them. I have counted them too.

That means it’s the same business. Don’t count those.

posts.name: Amodh Naik
posts.cooked: Well then my answer for Q2 gets skewed even further away from the options

posts.name: Rajat Shenoi
posts.cooked: Check it, all of us are getting right answers for that, the problem is only for Q3 not Q2. Recheck where you’re going wrong.

posts.name: Yazad Pardiwala
posts.cooked:
AmodhNaik:

I would like to add that I have attempted using geodesic and geopy.distance

Bit of a dumb question & I’m 94% sure the answer is “yes obviously I checked this”, but are you sure you’re using the correct distance formula?

From everything I’ve looked up, geopy.distance.distance does not return the distance the questions are expecting. Specifically it calculates distance using a model of the earth where it is a uniform ellipse.

By contrast the Haversine formula they’ve asked for assumes the earth is a big sphere. For that, use the geopy.distance.great_circle() formula.

posts.name: Amodh Naik
posts.cooked: Thank you so so much, a blunder on my part not realizing they wanted Haversine

posts.name: Amodh Naik
posts.cooked: After using the great_circle() formula, my code produces an answer 1 greater than any of the options (highest option is 220,796, I’m getting 220,797). I’ve tried not using <= and just < instead, but am still at a loss. Any ideas?

posts.name: Yazad Pardiwala
posts.cooked:
First & most important, like someone else mentioned, make sure you’re not including distance(id_614, id_614) = 0 in your count (I just initialized my matrix/dataframe with np.inf to address that).

Beyond that, honestly I did not even write code for the part of actually counting pairs. I just saved the dataframe as eateries_pairwise_distances.xlsx, opened it in excel (that took a hot minute), then selected the whole range & did countif() so I have no guesses on what pandas oculd be managing to do here.

205,839 - 205,842

I don’t know if in TDS ppl are alloted different datasets/questions & options as a matter of procedure, presumably they are; IF NOT then this may be an error - my options go from 316904 to 316908 (and the correct answer was included in that range).

posts.cooked: No, the questions are different for each student and therefore so are the option choices. It seems that universally however, a lot of students are getting an answer for Q3 that is exactly 1 above the highest available option for that question. That seems to be a common issue.

posts.name: Krishnakumar S
posts.cooked: i too face this for q3 what to do for this

posts.name: Vijay
posts.cooked: One basic question here, with 3000 odd stores in eateries.csv, calculating distance between each pair once takes a lot of time. Is there an efficient method that we should look for?

posts.name: SM Arif Ali
posts.cooked:
Use Vectorization

G.A. 6 Q2, Q3, Pairwise distances for all businesses - is there an efficient way? Tools in Data Science
The first big optimization you would do is cut the duplicate calculations that your logic would have. You only need to compute the top half of the triangular matrix, the rest would be just duplicate calculations if you visualise the relationships between the sets of businesses as a matrix. For loops with pandas is one the most inefficient way to deal with pandas dataframes. For all you aspiring data scientists, if you want to level up from pottering panda to Kung fu panda, Please read on… Effi…

posts.name: Shivansh Pande
posts.cooked:
@RajatShenoi,
I am facing a lot of problem in finding an answer of this even 1 off the options.
I have tried:

  1. Removing duplicates in terms of same latitude and longitude separately, got thousands of rows less than the options
  2. Removing duplicates considering name,latitude and longitude, got closer but still 2k off
    Why can it be so? I am using great circle distance, still answers are off.

posts.name: Vijay
posts.cooked: Thanks a lot for the reference, Arif

posts.name: Rajat Shenoi
posts.cooked:
Are you dividing by 2 somewhere?

  • If yes, are you first dividing and then subtracting the ones with zero distance or first subtracting and then dividing? You should do the latter.
  • If no, I don’t really know what else you could be doing wrong.

posts.name: Shivansh Pande
posts.cooked: Is 1. or 2. the way to go? 1. and 2… are according to options I tried.
